D8932B60DFE60131AB2D68A86D17958E.description: propose an action plan to address the issue of how to solve the problem

D892D940DFE60131AB2C68A86D17958E.description: prioritize the solutions based on established criteria

D8928F40DFE60131AB2B68A86D17958E.description: evaluate the consequences for each alternative solution or course of action

D8924880DFE60131AB2A68A86D17958E.description: suggest alternative solutions or courses of action to hypothetical or historic problems

D891FC50DFE60131AB2968A86D17958E.description: participate in activities that focus on a classroom, school, or community issue or problem

D891A120DFE60131AB2868A86D17958E.description: show a willingness to consider other points of view before drawing conclusions or making judgments

D8913D90DFE60131AB2768A86D17958E.description: The study of civics and citizenship requires the ability to probe ideas and assumptions, ask and answer analytical questions, take a skeptical attitude toward questionable arguments, evaluate evidence, formulate rational conclusions, and develop and refine participatory skills.

D88A2CE0DFE60131AB2668A86D17958E.description: identify basic rights that students have and those that they will acquire as they age

D889C0A0DFE60131AB2568A86D17958E.description: understand that effective, informed citizenship is a duty of each citizen, demonstrated by jury service, voting, and community service

D8897800DFE60131AB2468A86D17958E.description: examine the basic principles of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitutions of the United States and New York State

D8892F90DFE60131AB2368A86D17958E.description: identify and describe the rules and responsibilities students have at home, in the classroom, and at school

D888E110DFE60131AB2268A86D17958E.description: examine what it means to be a good citizen in the classroom, school, home, and community

D8889410DFE60131AB2168A86D17958E.description: understand that citizenship includes an awareness of the holidays, celebrations, and symbols of our nation

D8884F50DFE60131AB2068A86D17958E.description: Central to civics and citizenship is an understanding of the roles of the citizen within American constitutional democracy and the scope of a citizen's rights and responsibilities.

D88809D0DFE60131AB1F68A86D17958E.description: identify their legislative and executive representatives at the local, state, and national governments (Adapted from The National Standards for Civics and Government, 1994)

D887C460DFE60131AB1E68A86D17958E.description: understand the structure of New York State and local governments including executive, legislative, and judicial branches

D8877A50DFE60131AB1D68A86D17958E.description: understand that the United States Constitution and the Constitution of the State of New York are written plans for organizing the functions of government

D88725F0DFE60131AB1C68A86D17958E.description: know what the United States Constitution is and why it is important (Adapted from The National Standards for Civics and Government, 1994)

D886DDF0DFE60131AB1B68A86D17958E.description: understand the basic civil values that are the foundation of American constitutional democracy

D8869290DFE60131AB1A68A86D17958E.description: explain how the Constitutions of New York State and the United States and the Bill of Rights are the basis for democratic values in the United States

D88642E0DFE60131AB1968A86D17958E.description: The state and federal governments established by the Constitutions of the United States and the State of New York embody basic civic values (such as justice, honesty, self-discipline, due process, equality, majority rule with respect for minority rights, and respect for self, others, and property), principles, and practices and establish a system of shared and limited government. (Adapted from The National Standards for Civics and Government, 1994)

D885FF70DFE60131AB1868A86D17958E.description: discuss how and why the world is divided into nations and what kinds of governments other nations have

D885B860DFE60131AB1768A86D17958E.description: understand that social and political systems are based upon people's beliefs

D88561D0DFE60131AB1668A86D17958E.description: describe the basic purposes of government and the importance of civic life

D8850CA0DFE60131AB1568A86D17958E.description: explain the probable consequences of the absence of government and rules

D884BB60DFE60131AB1468A86D17958E.description: know the meaning of key terms and concepts related to government, including democracy, power, citizenship, nation-state, and justice

D8846360DFE60131AB1368A86D17958E.description: The study of civics, citizenship, and government involves learning about political systems; the purposes of government and civic life; and the differing assumptions held by people across time and place regarding power, authority, governance, and law. (Adapted from The National Standards for Civics and Government, 1994)

D883FAB0DFE60131AB1268A86D17958E.description: Students will use a variety of intellectual skills to demonstrate their understanding of the necessity for establishing governments; the governmental system of the United States and other nations; the United States Constitution; the basic civic values of American constitutional democracy; and the roles, rights, and responsibilities of citizenship, including avenues of participation.

D8836910DFE60131AB1068A86D17958E.description: present economic information by developing charts, tables, diagrams, and simple graphs

D88327F0DFE60131AB0F68A86D17958E.description: make hypotheses about economic issues and problems, testing, refining, and eliminating hypotheses and developing new ones when necessary

D882E610DFE60131AB0E68A86D17958E.description: collect economic information from textbooks, standard references, newspapers, periodicals, and other primary and secondary sources

D882A210DFE60131AB0D68A86D17958E.description: locate economic information, using card catalogues, computer databases, indices, and library guides

D88258A0DFE60131AB0C68A86D17958E.description: Economics requires the development and application of the skills needed to make informed and well-reasoned economic decisions in daily and national life.

D8820940DFE60131AB0B68A86D17958E.description: investigate how production, distribution, exchange, and consumption of goods and services are economic decisions with which all societies and nations must deal

D881C310DFE60131AB0A68A86D17958E.description: understand how societies organize their economies to answer three fundamental economic questions: What goods and services shall be produced and in what quantities ? How shall goods and services be produced? For whom shall goods and services be produced?

D8817E40DFE60131AB0968A86D17958E.description: study about how the availability and distribution of resources is important to a nation's economic growth

D8813BF0DFE60131AB0868A86D17958E.description: know that scarcity requires individuals to make choices and that these choices involve costs

D880F770DFE60131AB0768A86D17958E.description: explain how people's wants exceed their limited resources and that this condition defines scarcity

D880ADA0DFE60131AB0668A86D17958E.description: know some ways individuals and groups attempt to satisfy their basic needs and wants by utilizing scarce resources

D8805C10DFE60131AB0568A86D17958E.description: The study of economics requires an understanding of major economic concepts and systems, the principles of economic decision making, and the interdependence of economies and economic systems throughout the world.

D88009D0DFE60131AB0468A86D17958E.description: Students will use a variety of intellectual skills to demonstrate their understanding of how the United States and other societies develop economic systems and associated institutions to allocate scarce resources, how major decision-making units function in the United States and other national economies, and how an economy solves the scarcity problem through market and nonmarket mechanisms.

D87F69A0DFE60131AB0268A86D17958E.description: analyze geographic information by making relationships, interpreting trends and relationships, and analyzing geographic data. (Adapted from National Geography Standards, 1994)

D87F1CD0DFE60131AB0168A86D17958E.description: gather and organize geographic information from a variety of sources and display in a number of ways

D87EC730DFE60131AB0068A86D17958E.description: ask geographic questions about where places are located; why they are located where they are; what is important about their locations; and how their locations are related to the location of other people and places (Adapted from National Geography Standards, 1994)

D87E72A0DFE60131AAFF68A86D17958E.description: Geography requires the development and application of the skills of asking and answering geographic questions; analyzing theories of geography; and acquiring, organizing, and analyzing geographic information. (Adapted from: The National Geography Standards, 1994: Geography for Life)

D87E2AC0DFE60131AAFE68A86D17958E.description: investigate how people depend on and modify the physical environment

D87DE870DFE60131AAFD68A86D17958E.description: identify and compare the physical, human, and cultural characteristics of different regions and people (Adapted from National Geography Standards, 1994)

D87DA590DFE60131AAFC68A86D17958E.description: locate places within the local community, State, and nation; locate the Earth's continents in relation to each other and to principal parallels and meridians (Adapted from National Geography Standards, 1994)

D87D61B0DFE60131AAFB68A86D17958E.description: draw maps and diagrams that serve as representations of places, physical features, and objects

D87D1AB0DFE60131AAFA68A86D17958E.description: study about how people live, work, and utilize natural resources

D87CC980DFE60131AAF968A86D17958E.description: Geography can be divided into six essential elements which can be used to analyze important historic, geographic, economic, and environmental questions and issues. These six elements include: the world in spatial terms, places and regions, physical settings (including natural resources), human systems, environment and society, and the use of geography. (Adapted from The National Geography Standards, 1994: Geography for Life)

D87C8560DFE60131AAF868A86D17958E.description: Students will use a variety of intellectual skills to demonstrate their understanding of the geography of the interdependent world in which we live—local, national, and global—including the distribution of people, places, and environments over the Earth's surface.

D87BFD50DFE60131AAF668A86D17958E.description: view historic events through the eyes of those who were there, as shown in their art, writings, music, and artifacts

D87BB6F0DFE60131AAF568A86D17958E.description: explore the lifestyles, beliefs, traditions, rules and laws, and social/cultural needs and wants of people during different periods in history and in different parts of the world

D87B6A40DFE60131AAF468A86D17958E.description: consider different interpretations of key events and developments in world history and understand the differences in these accounts

D87B1610DFE60131AAF368A86D17958E.description: The skills of historical analysis include the ability to investigate differing and competing interpretations of the theories of history, hypothesize about why interpretations change over time, explain the importance of historical evidence, and understand the concepts of change and continuity over time.

D87AC560DFE60131AAF268A86D17958E.description: understand how the terms social, political, economic, and cultural can be used to describe human activities or practices

D87A7870DFE60131AAF168A86D17958E.description: gather and present information about important developments from world history

D87A1340DFE60131AAF068A86D17958E.description: understand the roles and contributions of individuals and groups to social, political, economic, cultural, scientific, technological, and religious practices and activities

D879CD70DFE60131AAEF68A86D17958E.description: Study of the major social, political, cultural, and religious developments in world history involves learning about the important roles and contributions of individuals and groups.

D87981F0DFE60131AAEE68A86D17958E.description: compare important events and accomplishments from different time periods in world history

D8792720DFE60131AAED68A86D17958E.description: measure and understand the meaning of calendar time in terms of years, decades, centuries, and millennia, using BC and AD as reference points

D878DEB0DFE60131AAEC68A86D17958E.description: develop timelines that display important events and eras from world history

D8789610DFE60131AAEB68A86D17958E.description: distinguish between past, present, and future time periods

D87852A0DFE60131AAEA68A86D17958E.description: Establishing timeframes, exploring different periodizations, examining themes across time and within cultures, and focusing on important turning points in world history help organize the study of world cultures and civilizations.

D8780E60DFE60131AAE968A86D17958E.description: study about different world cultures and civilizations focusing on their accomplishments, contributions, values, beliefs, and traditions

D877C6D0DFE60131AAE868A86D17958E.description: explore narrative accounts of important events from world history to learn about different accounts of the past to begin to understand how interpretations and perspectives develop

D87777A0DFE60131AAE768A86D17958E.description: read historical narratives, myths, legends, biographies, and autobiographies to learn about how historical figures lived, their motivations, hopes, fears, strengths, and weaknesses

D8772EB0DFE60131AAE668A86D17958E.description: The study of world history requires an understanding of world cultures and civilizations, including an analysis of important ideas, social and cultural values, beliefs, and traditions. This study also examines the human condition and the connections and interactions of people across time and space and the ways different people view the same event or issue from a variety of perspectives.

D876EBD0DFE60131AAE568A86D17958E.description: Students will use a variety of intellectual skills to demonstrate their understanding of major ideas, eras, themes, developments, and turning points in world history and examine the broad sweep of history from a variety of perspectives.

D87665B0DFE60131AAE368A86D17958E.description: view historic events through the eyes of those who were there, as shown in their art, writings, music, and artifacts.

D8761AC0DFE60131AAE268A86D17958E.description: explore different experiences, beliefs, motives, and traditions of people living in their neighborhoods, communities, and State

D875BB90DFE60131AAE168A86D17958E.description: consider different interpretations of key events and/or issues in history and understand the differences in these accounts

D8756860DFE60131AAE068A86D17958E.description: The skills of historical analysis include the ability to: explain the significance of historical evidence; weigh the importance, reliability, and validity of evidence; understand the concept of multiple causation; understand the importance of changing and competing interpretations of different historical developments.

D87517D0DFE60131AADF68A86D17958E.description: identify individuals who have helped to strengthen democracy in the United States and throughout the world

D874D5A0DFE60131AADE68A86D17958E.description: classify information by type of activity: social, political, economic, technological, scientific, cultural, or religious

D8748EA0DFE60131AADD68A86D17958E.description: gather and organize information about the important accomplishments of individuals and groups, including Native American Indians, living in their neighborhoods and communities

D87445D0DFE60131AADC68A86D17958E.description: Study about the major social, political, economic, cultural, and religious developments in New York State and United States history involves learning about the important roles and contributions of individuals and groups.

D873FCB0DFE60131AADB68A86D17958E.description: distinguish between near and distant past and interpret simple timelines

D873B6B0DFE60131AADA68A86D17958E.description: recognize how traditions and practices were passed from one generation to the next

D8736220DFE60131AAD968A86D17958E.description: gather and organize information about the traditions transmitted by various groups living in their neighborhood and community

D872F3F0DFE60131AAD868A86D17958E.description: Important ideas, social and cultural values, beliefs, and traditions from New York State and United States history illustrate the connections and interactions of people and events across time and from a variety of perspectives.

D8729DB0DFE60131AAD768A86D17958E.description: explain those values, practices, and traditions that unite all Americans

D8724FD0DFE60131AAD668A86D17958E.description: understand the basic ideals of American democracy as explained in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution and other important documents

D87208F0DFE60131AAD568A86D17958E.description: know the roots of American culture, its development from many different traditions, and the ways many people from a variety of groups and backgrounds played a role in creating it

D871B6A0DFE60131AAD468A86D17958E.description: The study of New York State and United States history requires an analysis of the development of American culture, its diversity and multicultural context, and the ways people are unified by many values, practices, and traditions.

D8714780DFE60131AAD368A86D17958E.description: Students will use a variety of intellectual skills to demonstrate their understanding of major ideas, eras, themes, developments, and turning points in the history of the United States and New York.

D870D990DFE60131AAD268A86D17958E.description: History of the United States and New York
